div1.head: Essay: Gust E. Lambert - Yellow Fever Nurse, by [Paul L. Tate], [1954]
div1.p: GUST E. LAMBERT - - Yellow Fever Nurse

No one reads much about Lambert, the most successful and
experienced of all yellow fever nurses, except that he was
termed, “Doctor Ames' Man Friday,” which was an apt appel-
lation, and Ames, thought highly of him.

At that time he was about 25 years of age, of athletic build
and exceptionally strong. He had been a seaman on sailing
ships from the age of 12, uneducated, but quick to learn.
Despite a rough, tough life all over the world as seaman and
later as a high steel construction worker, he had a decided
religious streak.--Never swore, drank, or lied. But he was
a tough Swede who gained his manhood, according to the
Scandinavian deep-sea law, at the age of 17, aboard ship,
when in a bloody fight disabled a man older and bigger than
himself, who had abused him. --A man who had 13 teeth pulled
refusing all an anesthetic, yet he was a kind and gentle
nurse.

Doctor Ames was his ideal.--The man who had taught him yel-
low fever nursing from post-mortem back to diagnosis. He
became the ideal nurse. Obeyed orders implicitly and could
handle the strongest patient gently and easily.--No strug-
gling, which often brought on black-vomit. A man who stayed
with his patients, constantly on duty, with no comforts or
relief.

He became indispensible to Ames. After handling over 67
cases of uyellow fever he had learned to see tohe fever as an
old nurse can see death, by a sixth sense.

This he once proved when Doctor Ames came to the yellow
fever ward one evening and asked him for a dringk of whiskey,
saying he thought he had malaria. Lambert knew that Ames
did not drink strong liquor, so he looked at him intently,
surprised, and told him, “You have yellow fever!”

✓ Ames said that was not possible. But Lambert insisted, and
with tears running down his cheeks, forced Ames to undergo
the preliminary treatment for that disease. Ames knew that
Lambert was so much in earnest that he dare not resist him.
✓ Next morning test showed no malaria and later on Captain
Stark diagnosised it as yellow fever.

I can still remember Lambert stuck in that fever section,
✓ in the miserable shacks before and until completion of the
experiments, eight months alone, nursing successfully all
those patients. Treated as an outcast, no one allowed near
him but the doctor; he allowed to go near no other, while
just across the cut he could see his fellow corpsmen enjoy-
ing a normal life. His uniform,-pajamas and slippers and
not even a chance to wash them--burned them and used new
ones.

Perhaps he did not know; perhaps he did, but he would never
have been compelled to remain all that time on a dangerous
job if he had protested. I well know that yellow fever
nursing in Cuba was in most cases that of volunteering. No
one was detailed to nurse that disease against his will.
